questions.question: Question 1: What is the primary mechanism of action of typical antipsychotics?
questions.explanation:
Typical or first-generation antipsychotics primarily act by postsynaptic D2 receptor blockade. The second-generation or atypical antipsychotics mainly act by blocking 5HT2A receptors but they 
also have weak D2 blocking effect. Histaminic H1 and muscarinic M1 receptors are blocked by most of the first and second 
generation agents. This contributes to sedation and anticholinergic effects of antipsychotics. Option C: Ropinirole and pramipexole are D2 agonists used in restless leg syndrome and 
Parkinson's disease. Option D: Lorcaserin is a 5HT2C agonist that was used to treat obesity. It was withdrawn in 2020 
as it was linked to increased cancer risk. Antipsychotics

questions.question:
Question 2: A patient with psychosis was prescribed an antipsychotic medication. Which one of the 
following side effects cannot be explained by the antagonistic action of the drug on D2 
receptors?
questions.explanation:
Constipation and dry mouth are side effects of antipsychotics that have potent antimuscarinic 
action. Hyperprolactinaemia, affective flattening, and rigidity in neuroleptic malignant syndrome occur 
due to D2 receptor blockade. 311 
Sold by @itachibot Apart from their action on D2 and 5-HT receptors, antipsychotic drugs also exert the following 
effects: Action of dru

questions.question:
Question 3: A woman presented with sudden onset high-grade fever, muscle rigidity, and altered 
sensorium. She had been on antipsychotic therapy with chlorpromazine. What is the most 
probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The features are suggestive of neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS) that is associated with the 
use of typical antipsychotics like chlorpromazine. Malignant neuroleptic syndrome is characterized by extreme muscle rigidity, fever, unstable BP 
and myoglobinemia. It can even lead to death. It can occur weeks to months after initiation of 
antipsychotic therapy and can persist for up to a week after discontinuation of the drug. The probable mechanism of this condition is dopamine antagonism. It is treated by stopping the offending antipsychotic immediately, supportive care, dantrolene, and 
bromocriptine.

questions.question:
Question 4: 304 
Sold by @itachibot A 28-year-old patient presents to the OPD with complaints of a brownish hue to her vision 
since 2 weeks. She has a history of being on antipsychotic medication for the past 10 weeks. 
Complete workup reveals pigmentary retinopathy in this patient. Which of the following 
drugs is implicated in this condition?
questions.explanation:
The pigmentary retinopathy seen in this patient is an adverse effect seen with the use 
of thioridazine which is a typical antipsychotic. In advanced cases, the deposits may resemble retinitis pigmentosa and the deposits are associated 
with 'browning of vision'. The drug is rarely used as it causes prolongation of QTc interval.

questions.question:
Question 5: A patient having both positive and negative symptoms of schizophrenia was prescribed an 
atypical antipsychotic with partial D2 agonism. Identify the drug.
questions.explanation:
Aripiprazole is an atypical antipsychotic showing D2 partial agonism. It has a higher affinity for 
D2 receptors than for 5HT2A receptors. As a partial agonist, aripiprazole has a dual-action which makes it useful in patients with both 
positive and negative symptoms of schizophrenia. Options A & D: Clozapine and risperidone are atypical antipsychotics with predominant 
5HT2A antagonistic activity over D2 antagonism. Option B: Fluphenazine is a typical antipsychotic. They have predominant D2 antagonism 
property and such action on the mesocortical pathway may increase the negative symptoms of 312 
Sold by @itachibot schizophrenia.

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following atypical antipsychotics is a preferential D3 receptor partial agonist?
questions.explanation:
Cariprazine is an atypical antipsychotic which is also a preferential D3 receptor partial 
agonist. Like other atypical antipsychotics, it also blocks D2 and 5-HT2 receptors. Option A: Aripiprazole is a dual D2/D3 partial agonist but it has no preference for the D3 receptor. Option C: Clozapine is a D2 receptor antagonist. Option D: Amisulpride is a D2 and D3 receptor antagonist.

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following antipsychotics should be given sublingually?
questions.explanation:
Asenapine is only available as an orally disintegrating tablet preparation that has to be 
administered sublingually. It undergoes very high first-pass metabolism and so bioavailability is very low via the oral route. 
Hence, sublingual administration is preferred.

questions.question:
Question 8: A schizophrenic patient was initiated on haloperidol therapy. 2 days later he presented to the 
OPD with deviation of his eyes, asymmetric neck posture and inability to open his mouth 
completely. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given scenario of deviation of the eyes (oculogyric crisis), asymmetric position of the head or 
neck (torticollis) and inability to open the mouth (trismus) are pointing towards a diagnosis of 
haloperidol-induced acute dystonia. These extrapyramidal symptoms (EPS) occur due to the antagonism of dopamine D2 receptors. Acute dystonia is more commonly associated with high potency typical antipsychotics like 
haloperidol and occurs within 1 to 5 days of initiation of therapy. Benztropine or 
diphenhydramine may be used for treatment.

questions.question:
Question 9: A 50-year-old man complains of feeling restless and irritable with an irresistible urge to 
move. He had recently been started on antipsychotic therapy with haloperidol. He appears 
agitated and paces up and down the room. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The features mentioned are suggestive of akathisia that is commonly associated with the use of 
high potency typical antipsychotics like haloperidol. Akathisia is described as subjective complaints of restlessness accompanied by observed 
movements such as movement of the legs, rocking from foot to foot, pacing, or inability to sit or 
stand still. It can occur at any time after 5-60 days from starting the drug. Treatment of akathisia: • Following a slower dose titration schedule, dose reduction, or switching to a less potent 
antipsychotic 313 
Sold by @itachibot • First-line drugs - beta-blockers • Second line drugs - benzodiazepines like lorazepam • Third line drugs - anticholinergic agents like trihexyphenidyl, benztropine

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following drugs does not cause neuroleptic malignant syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Amantadine does not cause neuroleptic malignant syndrome. Neuroleptic malignant syndrome resembles very severe parkinsonism and is caused by D2 
receptor antagonists. Amantadine increases the presynaptic release of dopamine and has agonist 
and modulatory action at postsynaptic D2 receptors. Option C: Quetiapine is an atypical antipsychotic. Although this class of antipsychotics has a lower 
chance of causing NMS compared to typical antipsychotics, but cases of fatal NMS following the 
administration of quetiapine have been recorded. Options B and D: Metoclopramide and domperidone are gastro kinetic agents with D2 
antagonism. Although domperidone has restricted entry across blood-brain barrier when 
compared to metoclopramide, there are reports of NMS with this agent.

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following effects of chlorpromazine is not due to its antidopaminergic activity?
questions.explanation:
Orthostatic hypotension is due to the alpha-receptor blocking the action of chlorpromazine. Chlorpromazine is a typical or first-generation antipsychotic with D2 blocking and additional 
alpha-receptor-blocking and anticholinergic activity. Option A: Dopamine inhibits prolactin release causing hypoprolactinemia and 
hence antidopaminergic action of chlorpromazine causes hyperprolactinemia. Option B: Extrapyramidal side effects occur due to D2 antagonism in the nigrostriatal region. Option C: The antiemetic action is due to D2 antagonism in the chemoreceptor trigger zone (CTZ). 314 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 12: Which of the following atypical antipsychotics has the highest risk of galactorrhea?
questions.explanation: Among atypical antipsychotics, risperidone and paliperidone have the highest risk of galactorrhea. The adverse effect occurs due to their higher D2 blocking potency.

questions.question:
Question 13: A 24-year-old with schizophrenia has not responded to adequate treatment with two different 
antipsychotics. Which of the following would be the drug of choice for his condition?
questions.explanation:
The drug of choice for treatment-resistant schizophrenia is clozapine. Treatment-resistant schizophrenia is the lack of response to two different antipsychotics given at 
adequate dosages for a minimum duration of 4-6 weeks. If patients demonstrate even a mild 
amount of improvement during this period, it may be reasonable to wait before changing the 
medication, since patients may improve at a steady rate for 3-6 months.

questions.question:
Question 14: A 50-year-old man is brought to the casualty following an episode of seizure. He says he was 
recently switched to a higher dose of his antipsychotic medication. Which drug is he most 
likely on?
questions.explanation:
The drug most likely implicated here is clozapine as it has the highest risk of precipitating 
seizures. It causes dose-dependent lowering of the seizure threshold. Clozapine-associated seizures can be treated with sodium valproate. Clozapine side effects: (Mnemonic - “Some say Clozapine has too many nasty adverse effects”) • Seizures • Sedation • Constipation 315 
Sold by @itachibot • Hypotension/hypersalivation • Tachycardia • Mass increase: weight gain and increased appetite • Nausea and vomiting • Agranulocytosis (neutropenia) • Enuresis and polyuria

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following is not true regarding clozapine?

options.a: More potently blocks D2 as compared to D1 receptors
options.b: Drug concentration is kept below 350ng/ml to avoid agranulocytosis
options.c: Should not be used along with carbamazepine
options.d: Should be discontinued if the neutrophil count is below 500/microL

questions.explanation:
Agranulocytosis is an immune-mediated adverse effect and unlike seizures, it is not dependent on 
dose. Thus, agranulocytosis can happen at any plasma concentration of clozapine and 
concentration < 350 ng/mL does not lower the risk. Option A: Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic, which acts by blocking the 5HT2,  2 and D4 
receptors. The potency of block is D4 > D2 >D1. Option C: Concomitant administration of carbamazepine with clozapine is contraindicated 
because of the increased risk of leukopenia. In addition, carbamazepine is an enzyme inducer and 
reduces the half-life of clozapine. Option D: Administration of clozapine requires regular blood count monitoring due to the risk of 
agranulocytosis. Monitoring is performed weekly for the first 6 months and once in two weeks for 
the next 6 months. Patients must be asked to report for evaluation in case of symptoms such as 
fever or sore throat. Clozapine should be discontinued if the neutrophil count drops below 500 
cells/L.

questions.question:
Question 16: A 34-year-old woman presented to the ophthalmology OPD with complaints of diminution of 
vision. She has bipolar disorder and has been on antipsychotic therapy for the past 8 months. 
Ophthalmic examination revealed the finding seen in the below image . What drug was she 
most likely on?
questions.explanation:
The image shows a whitish opacity in the pupillary region and this in combination with the 
presenting features are suggestive of cataract. This is an adverse effect seen with the use of 
quetiapine which is an atypical antipsychotic.

questions.question: Question 17: Which of the following antipsychotics cause QT prolongation at therapeutic doses?
questions.explanation: Haloperidol, quetiapine and ziprasidone cause QT prolongation at therapeutic doses.

questions.question:
Question 18: Patient X and patient Y are on different antipsychotics. X has gained a lot of weight and has 
been feeling dizzy when she stands. Y has not gained weight, but is very restless and keeps 
pacing around the room. The drugs they are most likely taking are:
questions.explanation:
The most likely option amongst the given options is: Patient X is taking olanzapine which has side effects of weight gain and hypotension. 316 
Sold by @itachibot Olanzapine and clozapine account for most cases of weight gain and drug-induced diabetes 
mellitus. Patient Y is taking haloperidol and has developed the side effect of akathisia. This is an 
extrapyramidal effect in which the patient is restless, irritable, and feels an urge to keep moving. Haloperidol has a high risk of developing extrapyramidal side effects such as akathisia, dystonia, 
and tardive dyskinesia.

questions.question: Question 19: Which of the following is a side effect of ziprasidone?
questions.explanation:
Ziprasidone causes prolongation of QT interval. It should be avoided in patients with a history of 
cardiac arrhythmias and should not be given in combination with other drugs known to prolong 
the QT interval. The other options mentioned are side effects of clozapine.

questions.question:
Question 20: A 45-year-old woman suffering from Huntington's chorea is on haloperidol. Which of the 
following adverse drug effects is best attributed to the supersensitivity of dopamine 
receptors?

options.a: Muscle rigidity, labile blood pressure, hyperreflexia, hyperthermia, tachycardia, tremors
options.b: Lip smacking, facial dyskinesia, protrusion and rolling of the tongue, involuntary movements of
options.c: Facial grimacing, involuntary upward eye movement, laryngeal spasm and arching of the trunk
options.d: Stooped posture, rigidity, shuffling gait, bradykinesia, and pill rolling tremors

questions.explanation:
Lip-smacking, facial dyskinesia, protrusion and rolling of the tongue, and involuntary movements 
of the extremities are characteristic of tardive dyskinesia. This is caused by supersensitivity of 
dopamine receptors. It occurs as a consequence of chronic postsynaptic D2 receptor blockade by antipsychotics, which 
results in upregulation and supersensitivity of postsynaptic dopamine receptors. Tardive dyskinesia is usually seen in patients treated with typical antipsychotics (first generation) 
for more than a year. This may be reversible with early recognition and drug discontinuation. 
Treatment is with valbenazine, deutetrabenazine (VMAT2 inhibitors).

questions.question:
Question 21: A 24-year-old man is brought by his family with complaints of mental instability. On 
questioning, he says that he sees his grandparents in the room and talks to them often but the 
family confirms that it's been 10 years since his grandparents passed away. He was then 
prescribed an antipsychotic drug following which he developed parkinsonism. Which of the 309 
Sold by @itachibot following antiviral drugs■ can be used for treating his condition?
questions.explanation:
Amantadine is an antiviral agent that is the most commonly used medication for 
antipsychotic-induced parkinsonism. It increases the concentration of dopamine (DA) at the synapse and appears to act by certain 
mechanisms like: • presynaptic DA reuptake blockade • facilitation of DA release • postsynaptic DA agonism • receptor modulation 317 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 22: Which of the following statement is false with respect to antipsychotics and pregnancy?

options.a: Can be given alone for acute episodes
options.b: Serum concentration monitoring is not used for dose adjustment
options.c: Cause benign and reversible flattening of T wave on ECG

questions.explanation:
The guidelines recommend continuing the same antipsychotic, as switching the drug during 
pregnancy would cause a higher rate of relapse. Antipsychotic drugs and pregnancy: • Crossing the placenta: Olanzapine > Haloperidol > Risperidone > Quetiapine. • Olanzapine is unlikely to increase the risk of birth defects above the background population risk. 
However, it can cause low birth weight and increased NICU admissions. • Clozapine is associated with gestational diabetes and neonatal seizures. Note: Although antipsychotic drugs appear to be relatively safe in pregnancy, the available data 
does not provide adequate guidance on the choice of agent. Because of limited experience in 
humans, olanzapine should be used in pregnancy only when the potential benefit justifies the 
potential risk to the fetus. 318 
Sold by @itachibot Anti-manic Drugs
